study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether creatyl-L-leucine (CLL) could increase muscle creatine content compared to creatine monohydrate and placebo.
results_summary: The study found that CLL did not increase muscle creatine content, while creatine monohydrate significantly increased it. No changes were observed in the placebo or CLL groups.
population_specificity: Healthy men (n=17) and women (n=12), aged 28.5 ± 7.3 to 30.3 ± 6.9 years.
effective_dosage: 5 g/day of CLL or creatine monohydrate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether short-term resistance exercise training combined with a leucine-enriched protein bar enhances myofibrillar protein synthesis and anabolic signaling compared to exercise alone.
results_summary: Myofibrillar protein synthesis increased during resistance training, with further enhancement when combined with leucine supplementation. The leucine-enriched bar also boosted phosphorylation of key anabolic signaling proteins (mTOR and 4EBP1) compared to rest.
population_specificity: Eight young adults.
effective_dosage: 16 g of protein containing ~3 g of leucine per bar.
study_duration: Two 4-day phases separated by a 2-day washout.

study_goal: The researchers hypothesized that leucine, as a System L substrate, could potentially restrain immunosuppressive kynurenine and restore anti-tumour immunity.
results_summary: The study suggests that leucine supplementation may compete with kynurenine for entry into immune T-cells via the System L transporter, potentially mitigating immunosuppression. However, direct experimental evidence for leucine's efficacy in humans is not provided.
population_specificity: Preclinical (TDO-knockout mice and in vitro CD4+ T-cell studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and efficacy of leucine-enriched whey protein supplementation combined with resistance exercise training in improving muscle mass and strength in geriatric rehabilitation patients with sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study assessed feasibility (adherence, dropout rate) and changes in muscle mass, strength, and functional performance. Results indicated potential benefits, but full efficacy data were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Geriatric rehabilitation inpatients with sarcopenia (n=80 in the RCT arm).
effective_dosage: Leucine and vitamin D-enriched whey protein-based oral nutritional supplement two times per day (exact leucine dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of leucine, along with other interventions, in mitigating muscle loss in critically ill patients.
results_summary: The study found that leucine supplementation, particularly when combined with whey protein and vitamin D, may help promote muscle synthesis and alleviate muscle loss in critically ill patients. It was noted as part of a broader strategy involving high protein intake and ergogenic aids.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients, particularly those experiencing muscle loss during hospitalization and post-discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether leucine supplementation combined with a calorie-restricted diet could improve body composition and resting metabolic rate in mid-life overweight and obese women.
results_summary: Both groups lost weight, including fat and lean mass, but leucine supplementation did not significantly differ from placebo in preserving lean mass or affecting RMR. A greater proportion of women taking leucine maintained or gained lean mass, though this was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Mid-life overweight and obese women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of leucine-enriched essential amino acids (LEAAs) on mTORC1 activation, the ubiquitin-proteasome system, and inflammatory cytokines following resistance exercise in young men.
results_summary: LEAA supplementation increased mTOR phosphorylation, suggesting enhanced anabolic signaling, but the abstract does not detail effects on catabolic systems or inflammatory cytokines.
population_specificity: 20 healthy young male subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of leucine supplementation in offsetting anabolic resistance and maintaining muscle mass for injured athletes during rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that leucine supplementation is feasible and effective in counteracting anabolic resistance, supporting muscle mass maintenance without fat gain. Combined protein and carbohydrate intake during rehabilitation was noted to inhibit muscle breakdown and atrophy.
population_specificity: Injured athletes undergoing rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether combining resistance training with a leucine-rich amino acid supplement improves muscle strength, physical function, and muscle mass in elderly type 2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant additive effect of the leucine-rich supplement on muscle strength, physical function, or muscle mass compared to resistance training alone. However, resistance training (with or without the supplement) improved knee extension strength and reduced cognitive decline compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with type 2 diabetes (60 participants).
effective_dosage: 6 g of a leucine-rich amino acid supplement daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a leucine-enriched whey protein formula in improving physical performance and muscle mass in older adults with sarcopenia undergoing rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that the leucine-enriched formula significantly improved gait speed, muscle mass, physical performance, functional and cognitive outcomes, and reduced rehabilitation duration and hospital stay compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥65 years) with sarcopenia, without severe cognitive impairment, hospitalized for physical rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Twice daily (specific amount not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: At least 4 weeks and up to 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of leucine as a nutritional intervention for improving muscle mass in elderly individuals with sarcopenia.
results_summary: Leucine was found to have a significant effect on muscle mass in elderly people with sarcopenia, with the best available evidence supporting its recommendation. The study noted that the overall quality of evidence was low to moderate due to limited and varied reviews.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged ≥65 years with sarcopenia or its criteria (muscle mass, strength, or physical performance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review leucine's roles in lipid metabolism and energy homeostasis, focusing on its effects on fatty acid oxidation, lipolysis, and metabolic pathways.
results_summary: Leucine demonstrated anti-obesity effects by improving glucose tolerance, lipid metabolism, and insulin sensitivity, while also modulating mitochondrial dysfunction. It activated the AMPK-SIRT1-PGC-1α pathway and influenced adipokines and gut microbiota stability.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo and in vitro studies referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute anabolic response of a proprietary EAA/whey protein composition versus a whey protein-based recovery product, assessing dose-dependent effects on protein kinetics.
results_summary: The high-dose EAA/protein composition showed the greatest increase in net protein balance and muscle protein FSR, outperforming the whey-based supplement. Both doses of the EAA/protein blend were more anabolic per gram than the whey product, driven by enhanced protein synthesis and suppressed breakdown.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.
effective_dosage: 6.3 g (low dose) and 12.6 g (high dose) of the EAA/protein composition; 17 g of Gatorade Recover.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of 6 months of l-carnitine supplementation on platelet mitochondrial DNA methylation, lipid profile, and TMAO levels in aged women engaged in regular physical training.
results_summary: The study found that TMAO levels significantly increased after l-carnitine supplementation, suggesting a potential cardiovascular risk. Other outcomes like platelet mitochondrial DNA methylation and lipid profile were measured but not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Aged women engaged in regular physical training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether long-term leucine supplementation could normalize muscle protein synthesis and improve muscle strength, volume, and wellbeing in adolescents and adults with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation led to a 25.4% increase in muscle strength, a 3.6% increase in muscle volume, a 59.1% reduction in inflammation (CRP), and improved wellbeing, with no changes in metabolism or body composition.
population_specificity: Adolescents and adults with spastic cerebral palsy (mean age ~18 years).
effective_dosage: 192 mg/kg body mass dissolved in water, administered daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a whey protein supplement enriched with leucine, combined with resistance training, improved muscle mass and strength in post-hospitalized elderly individuals.
results_summary: Both the protein supplementation and placebo groups showed improvements in physical function after 12 weeks of resistance training, but the abstract does not specify whether leucine-enriched supplementation provided additional benefits over placebo.
population_specificity: Post-hospitalized elderly individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of administering a leucine-enriched essential amino acid (L-EAA) supplement to mechanically ventilated trauma patients and evaluate its effects on skeletal muscle mass and function.
results_summary: L-EAA delivery was feasible, but significant barriers to recruitment and outcome measurement were identified. No meaningful changes in functional or muscle mass outcomes were observed.
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated trauma patients in intensive care.
effective_dosage: 5 g L-EAA five times per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether leucine-enriched whey protein supplementation, with or without exercise, improves muscle fatigue, muscle mass, fat mass, and health-related quality of life in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that exercise alone (E) and exercise combined with leucine-enriched whey protein (EP) significantly improved resistance to muscle fatigue in the rectus femoris and bicep femoris muscles. The EP group showed notable but not superior effects compared to exercise alone.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (mean age 69 ± 6 years, 52% women).
effective_dosage: 1.5 g/kg/day of leucine-enriched whey protein, administered 3 times/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of leucine supplementation on sarcopenia in older individuals, focusing on muscle strength, lean mass, and physical performance.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation (1.2-6 g/day) was well-tolerated and significantly improved lean muscle mass in elderly individuals, though effects on muscle strength were mixed, and physical performance was rarely studied. Promising results were noted in post-stroke and liver cirrhosis patients.
population_specificity: Older individuals with sarcopenia, including those with aging-related sarcopenia or specific disorders like post-stroke and liver cirrhosis.
interactions: Vitamin D co-administration was common in protocols.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 13 weeks of leucine-enriched whey protein and Vitamin D supplementation could attenuate chronic low-grade inflammatory profile (CLIP) in older sarcopenic adults with mobility limitations.
results_summary: The study found that the supplementation attenuated the increase in IL-6 levels observed in the control group, suggesting a potential benefit in reducing CLIP progression. IL-8 levels decreased overall, while changes in pre-albumin predicted changes in IL-6.
population_specificity: Sarcopenic adults aged ≥65 years with mobility limitations and a BMI of 20-30 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers were examining whether leucine, among other nutrients, could help prevent or delay sarcopenia and functional decline in aging populations.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding leucine's effects, only mentioning it as a potential nutritional target for geriatric conditions.
population_specificity: Aging individuals at risk of sarcopenia and functional decline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a leucine-enriched amino acid supplement could improve muscle mass, strength, and physical function in post-stroke patients with sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study found that leucine supplementation significantly improved physical function (FIM score), handgrip strength, and skeletal muscle mass index (SMI) compared to the control group, with greater improvements in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Post-stroke older patients with sarcopenia (n=44).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether native whey protein, high in leucine, is more effective than regular whey protein or milk at stimulating muscle protein synthesis in elderly individuals post-exercise.
results_summary: Native whey increased blood leucine concentrations more than regular whey but did not significantly enhance muscle protein synthesis or p70S6K phosphorylation compared to regular whey. However, both whey supplements outperformed milk in increasing leucine levels and p70S6K phosphorylation, with native whey showing superior muscle protein synthesis effects over milk.
population_specificity: 21 healthy elderly men and women (≥70 years)
effective_dosage: 20 g of WPC-80, native whey, or milk, ingested immediately and two hours post-exercise
study_duration: Single-day intervention with measurements taken over a 5-hour post-exercise period

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether leucine-rich whey protein supplementation during weight loss helps preserve muscle mass and strength in middle-aged postmenopausal women with obesity.
results_summary: Whey protein supplementation reduced muscle loss at 5% weight loss but showed no significant difference at 10% weight loss. Muscle strength was unaffected by the dietary interventions.
population_specificity: Middle-aged (50-65 years old) postmenopausal women with obesity.
effective_dosage: Total protein intake of 1.2 g/kg/day (including whey protein supplementation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefit of opicinumab (a human monoclonal antibody against LINGO-1) compared to placebo on vision-related functioning and high-contrast visual acuity in patients with acute optic neuritis.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between opicinumab and placebo in improving vision-related functioning or high-contrast visual acuity by Week 24, with both groups showing substantial recovery from baseline. Average scores after recovery remained lower than those of disease-free controls.
population_specificity: Participants with acute optic neuritis (AON).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding leucine to a smaller dose of milk proteins would produce similar increases in muscle protein synthesis as a larger dose of whey protein isolate in older women.
results_summary: The study found that a lower-protein, leucine-matched beverage (10 g milk protein + 3 g leucine) induced similar or greater increases in acute and integrated muscle protein synthesis compared to a higher-dose whey protein isolate (25 g), particularly when combined with resistance exercise. The leucine-enriched supplement showed superior effects in the exercised leg.
population_specificity: Healthy older women (mean age 69 ± 1 years).
effective_dosage: 10 g milk protein + 3 g leucine (twice daily) or 25 g whey protein isolate (3 g leucine, twice daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whey hydrolysate, caseinate, and carbohydrate on muscle protein synthesis rates in older men at rest and after resistance exercise.
results_summary: Leucine concentrations varied after intake of different study drinks, but no significant differences in muscle protein synthesis rates were observed between groups. Both fed-rested and fed-exercised states showed higher synthesis rates than basal levels.
population_specificity: Older men (mean age 69 ± 1 year)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding leucine to a protein beverage enhances acute and integrated myofibrillar protein synthesis (myoPS) in older women compared to a mixed-protein beverage.
results_summary: The leucine-enriched beverage (4.2 g/serving) significantly increased acute and integrated myoPS in both rested and exercised legs compared to the control beverage (1.3 g leucine). The effects were more pronounced in the exercised leg.
population_specificity: Healthy older women aged 65-75 years.
effective_dosage: 15 g protein beverage (containing 4.2 g leucine) twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical outcome and cost-effectiveness of a 12-month nutritional intervention, including leucine, in muscle-wasted COPD patients undergoing pulmonary rehabilitation.
results_summary: The nutritional intervention improved plasma levels of supplemented nutrients, physical activity, body weight, and generic health status, but did not enhance long-term physical capacity outcomes compared to placebo. Anxiety and depression scores also improved in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Muscle-wasted COPD patients (51% male, average age 62.5 years) with moderate airflow obstruction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether leucine supplementation could improve muscle mass and function in older adults with sarcopenia.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study is described as an ongoing trial.
population_specificity: Adults aged 70+ with sarcopenia, defined by low skeletal muscle mass and either low gait speed or low handgrip strength.
interactions: Participants were excluded if already taking leucine or ACE inhibitors/ARBs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of L-leucine supplementation on glucose homeostasis in glucose-intolerant rodents and identify the best approach for future clinical trials.
results_summary: The systematic review included 34 studies and found that L-leucine supplementation improved metabolic outcomes in glucose-intolerant rodent models, though optimal dosages and conditions varied across studies.
population_specificity: Glucose-intolerant rodent models

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of leucine in macrophage lipid metabolism and its potential antiatherogenic properties.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation reduced cholesterol and triglyceride mass in macrophages by inhibiting biosynthesis and increasing efflux, while also improving mitochondrial respiration and ATP production. These effects were observed in humans, mice, and cultured macrophages.
population_specificity: Healthy adults, C57BL/6 mice, and J774A.1 murine macrophages.
effective_dosage: 5 g/d for humans; 0.2 mM for cultured macrophages.
study_duration: 3 weeks for humans; 8 weeks for mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute anabolic effects of native whey protein (higher in leucine), WPC-80, and milk protein on muscle protein synthesis and p70S6K phosphorylation after resistance exercise.
results_summary: Native whey increased blood leucine concentrations more than WPC-80 and milk but was not superior to WPC-80 in stimulating muscle protein synthesis or p70S6K phosphorylation. However, native whey outperformed milk in increasing p70S6K phosphorylation and muscle protein synthesis rates post-exercise.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract (likely healthy adults engaging in resistance exercise).
effective_dosage: 2 × 20 g doses of each protein type.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of leucine-enriched essential amino acids (EAA) and whey protein (WP) on muscle protein synthesis (MPS) in older women.
results_summary: Leucine-enriched EAA (even at 1.5 g) robustly stimulated MPS similarly to 40 g WP, with no additional benefit from higher doses. Composition (presence of leucine) was more crucial than the amount for anabolism.
population_specificity: Older women (65 ± 1 years).
effective_dosage: 1.5 g leucine-enriched EAA (LEAA_1.5), 6 g leucine-enriched EAA (LEAA_6), and 40 g whey protein (WP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore novel therapeutic options, including leucine supplementation, to address sarcopenia in alcoholic liver disease (ALD) and cirrhosis.
results_summary: The abstract suggests leucine supplementation is under preclinical evaluation as a potential therapy to prevent and reverse sarcopenia in ALD and cirrhosis, but specific results or outcomes are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with alcoholic liver disease (ALD) and cirrhosis, particularly those experiencing sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the Tolerable Upper Intake Level (UL) for leucine in young and elderly men to establish safe supplementation guidelines.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that leucine stimulates muscle protein synthesis and may help prevent sarcopenia, but the efficacious dose remains unknown. The study focuses on determining the UL by assessing leucine oxidation in young men.
population_specificity: Young and elderly men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether free essential amino acid (EAA) supplements, including leucine, are more effective than complete protein supplements in stimulating whole-body protein anabolism in COPD patients and healthy older adults.
results_summary: The study found that EAA supplements, including leucine, stimulated 42-49% higher net protein gain compared to complete protein supplements in both COPD patients and healthy controls. However, the high leucine content did not solely account for this effect, as net protein gain per gram EAA intake was lower for the EAA mixture.
population_specificity: 23 patients with moderate to very severe COPD (age 65±2 years) and healthy older adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate leucine's role in mitigating age-related anabolic resistance in muscle and its potential as a strategy to preserve or restore muscle mass in aging.
results_summary: Leucine enhances protein synthesis via mTORC1 activation but shows impaired responsiveness in aged muscle. While leucine supplementation can mitigate anabolic resistance, long-term high-dose use may pose risks like insulin resistance and tumorigenesis.
population_specificity: Aged individuals with muscle anabolic resistance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hyperinsulinemic-normoglycemic clamp combined with perioperative amino acid (including Leucine) supplementation improves whole-body protein balance in cardiac surgery patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Leucine's effects, only mentioning the study design and intervention.
population_specificity: 20 patients scheduled for elective coronary artery bypass grafting surgery.
study_duration: Intra- and postoperative period (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of whey protein supplementation, which includes leucine, on elderly individuals undergoing resistance training.
results_summary: Whey protein supplementation increased total protein intake and plasma leucine concentration, leading to higher mixed muscle protein synthesis rates compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals undergoing resistance training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary leucine supplementation could positively impact obesity-related metabolic disorders, including inflammation, lipid/glucose metabolism, and lean body mass preservation.
results_summary: The study found that leucine supplementation may improve body weight loss, reduce white adipose tissue inflammation, enhance mitochondrial function, and support metabolic health, though these effects are not yet clearly established.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity or obesity-induced metabolic disorders (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enriching a protein drink with leucine would enhance anabolic responses to resistance exercise in young and older adults.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study hypothesized that leucine enrichment would improve anabolic responses to resistance exercise in both age groups.
population_specificity: Young adults (24 ± 6 years, BMI 23 ± 2 kg/m²) and older adults (specific age not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of leucine in maintaining muscle health, particularly in older adults, and whether protein sources enriched with leucine or its metabolite could preserve muscle mass and function.
results_summary: The study suggests that older adults may require higher protein intake to counteract anabolic resistance, with leucine-enriched proteins offering the greatest benefit for muscle preservation. It highlights leucine's role as a key regulator of muscle protein turnover in aging populations.
population_specificity: Older adults at risk of insufficient protein ingestion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety of leucine supplementation in healthy elderly men by evaluating its effects on blood ammonia levels and oxidation rates.
results_summary: The study found that blood ammonia concentrations exceeded normal values at leucine intakes >550 mg/kg/day, and leucine oxidation plateaued after 450 mg/kg/day, suggesting an upper intake limit of ~500 mg/kg/day for elderly men.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly men (72.2 ± 3.5 years).
effective_dosage: Graded stepwise increases from 50 to 750 mg/kg/day on eight separate study days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of n-3 PUFA supplementation on the intravascular kinetics of apolipoprotein B-48-containing lipoproteins using L-[5,5,5-D3] leucine as a tracer in men with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that n-3 PUFA supplementation reduced fasting triglyceride concentrations but increased plasma cholesterol, LDL-C, and HDL-C levels. It had no significant effect on postprandial TRL apoB-48 and VLDL apoB-100 levels or their production/catabolic rates.
population_specificity: 10 men with type 2 diabetes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of leucine in maximizing muscle protein synthesis (MPS) and preserving muscle mass and strength in older adults.
results_summary: The study suggests that increasing the proportion of leucine in protein intake, alongside physical activity and co-ingestion of other nutrients, can enhance MPS and help preserve muscle mass and strength in older adults.
population_specificity: Older adults (healthy, with potential age-related muscle decline).
effective_dosage: Not specified for leucine alone; protein recommendations include 0.4-0.5 g/kg BM per meal (assuming three meals daily).
interactions: Co-ingestion with carbohydrates, fats, or n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids may enhance leucine's effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the molecular, physiologic, and phenotypic skeletal muscle responses to resistance exercise combined with protein/amino acid (including leucine) supplementation in young adults.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation (when exceeding 2 g/dose) showed no differences in strength or muscle mass outcomes compared to other protein types, but the overall effect size of protein/AA supplementation was low and highly variable among individuals. The study noted a diminishing effect of protein/AA supplements over prolonged resistance exercise training.
population_specificity: Young adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with leucine (4 g), combined with whey protein, essential amino acids, and vitamin D, alongside physical activity, could improve fat-free mass, strength, and overall well-being in sarcopenic elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation significantly increased fat-free mass, muscle strength, physical function, and nutritional status while reducing inflammation markers like C-reactive protein. The combination of leucine-containing supplements and exercise showed clinically meaningful improvements in multiple health metrics.
population_specificity: Sarcopenic elderly individuals (mean age 80.3 years; 53 men, 77 women).
effective_dosage: 4 g leucine (as part of 10.9 g essential amino acids) combined with 22 g whey protein and 2.5 μg vitamin D, administered daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of leucine in stimulating muscle protein synthesis and its potential as a preventative measure against sarcopenia, particularly in older adults.
results_summary: Leucine independently stimulates muscle protein synthesis, but age-specific changes reduce its effectiveness in older subjects when sub-maximal amounts are administered. Combining resistance exercise with nutritional supplementation (including leucine) enhances muscle anabolism and may help prevent sarcopenia.
population_specificity: Older adults, including healthy non-diabetic individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether leucine supplementation could protect skeletal muscle health (e.g., muscle protein synthesis, function, and mass) during 14 days of bed rest in middle-aged adults.
results_summary: Leucine partially protected muscle function (peak torque and endurance), reduced lean mass loss after 7 days, prevented increased body fat percentage, and maintained muscle quality after 14 days of bed rest, though it did not significantly affect muscle protein synthesis or cell signaling compared to the control.
population_specificity: Middle-aged adults (mean age 52 ± 1 years, n = 19)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate leucine's dual role in stimulating both anabolic (muscle protein synthesis) and catabolic (mitochondrial biogenesis) processes in metabolically active tissues.
results_summary: Leucine was found to effectively stimulate both muscle protein synthesis and oxidative metabolism via mitochondrial biogenesis, suggesting benefits beyond muscle hypertrophy. The study highlights the interplay between these processes but notes that the dependence of mitochondrial biogenesis on increased protein synthesis remains undefined.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of original investigations, likely involving metabolically active tissues such as muscle).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how protein-leucine supplementation affects skeletal-muscle protein synthesis, inflammatory responses, and molecular adaptations following strenuous endurance exercise.
results_summary: Protein-leucine supplementation dose-dependently modulated gene expression related to inflammation, muscle growth, and recovery, with higher doses promoting proinflammatory and promyogenic responses early and anti-inflammatory effects later. The supplement enhanced muscle regeneration processes, particularly through transcriptome networks involving cell viability, myocyte differentiation, and extracellular matrix development.
population_specificity: 12 trained men
effective_dosage: 70/15/180/30 g (protein-leucine-carbohydrate-fat) for 15LEU, 23/5/180/30 g for 5LEU, or 0/0/274/30 g for CON, ingested during the first 90 min of recovery

study_goal: To assess the effect of free leucine supplementation combined with resistance training versus resistance training alone on muscle strength and functional status in older adults.
results_summary: Clinically significant gains were found in isometric leg strength at both 4 and 12 weeks, with the leucine group outperforming the control group in chair stands and the timed up and go test. No significant changes were observed for other outcomes.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether soluble milk protein, rich in essential amino acids like leucine, could enhance muscle protein synthesis in elderly men.
results_summary: The study found that soluble milk proteins improved postprandial muscle protein synthesis, particularly for mitochondrial proteins and myosin, especially in high-protein diets. No significant increase was observed in sarcoplasmic proteins or actin.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly men (71.8 ± 2.4 years, n = 31).
effective_dosage: 15 g or 30 g of protein (PRO or CAS), given fractionally every 20 minutes for 4 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the macronutrient composition of a leucine-enriched whey protein supplement affects postprandial muscle protein synthesis rates in older men.
results_summary: Leucine-enriched whey protein significantly increased muscle protein synthesis rates in older men, but adding carbohydrate and fat did not further enhance this effect. Carbohydrate and fat alone did not increase muscle protein synthesis.
population_specificity: Nonsarcopenic older men (aged 69 ± 1 years, BMI 25.7 ± 0.3 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 21 g of leucine-enriched whey protein, either with (9 g carbohydrate, 3 g fat) or without additional macronutrients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a leucine-enriched whey protein supplement could improve measures of sarcopenia, such as muscle mass and physical function, in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that the leucine-enriched supplement improved lower-extremity function (chair-stand test) and increased appendicular muscle mass compared to the control group, though handgrip strength and SPPB scores did not differ significantly between groups.
population_specificity: Sarcopenic, primarily independent-living older adults with low skeletal muscle mass index and moderate physical performance limitations (SPPB scores 4-9).
effective_dosage: Twice daily (specific leucine dosage not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of leucine supplementation on anthropometrical parameters and muscle strength in the elderly, with a secondary focus on differentiating outcomes between healthy and sarcopenic subjects.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation significantly increased body weight, lean body mass, and body mass index, particularly in sarcopenic individuals, but did not significantly affect muscle strength or other metabolic biomarkers.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals, including both healthy and sarcopenic subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high whey protein-, leucine-, and vitamin D-enriched supplement could preserve muscle mass during intentional weight loss in obese older adults.
results_summary: The supplement preserved appendicular muscle mass (+0.4 kg vs. -0.5 kg in the control group) during weight loss, though muscle strength and function improvements did not differ significantly between groups. The intervention group had higher protein intake, but weight and fat loss were similar in both groups.
population_specificity: Obese older adults (mean age 63 ± 5.6 years, BMI 33 ± 4.4 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 150 kcal supplement (21 g protein, enriched with leucine and vitamin D) 10 times per week.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of leucine-rich protein supplementation on muscle protein synthesis, strength, and performance in older adults.
results_summary: Leucine-rich "fast" proteins like whey improved muscle protein synthesis. Supplementation with milk protein increased strength in frail older adults, but combining it with exercise only boosted muscle mass without additional strength or functionality benefits.
population_specificity: Older adults, including frail individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different protein sources (whey or soy) during a short-term hypoenergetic diet affected myofibrillar protein synthesis (MPS) and lipolysis.
results_summary: Whey protein supplementation attenuated the decline in postprandial MPS after weight loss compared to soy or carbohydrate, suggesting better preservation of lean mass. Lipolysis suppression was greater with carbohydrate ingestion than with soy or whey.
population_specificity: Men (n = 19) and women (n = 21) aged 35-65 with a BMI of 28-50 kg/m².
effective_dosage: 27 g whey protein or 26 g soy protein twice daily, totaling 1.3 ± 0.1 g/(kg · d) protein intake.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether leucine supplementation increases muscle protein fractional synthetic rate and improves lean body mass or leg lean mass in elderly patients.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation significantly increased muscle protein fractional synthetic rate compared to the control group, but no significant differences were found in lean body mass or leg lean mass.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether leucine supplementation could enhance muscle protein synthesis and improve growth in low birth weight infants.
results_summary: The study found that leucine and its metabolites (α-ketoisocaproic acid and β-hydroxy-β-methylbutyrate) have unique anabolic properties, and supplementation with leucine enhances muscle protein synthesis in neonatal pigs, suggesting potential benefits for low birth weight infants.
population_specificity: Neonatal pigs (as a model for low birth weight infants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the independent and combined effects of a multicomponent exercise program with and without a milk-based supplement rich in leucine on muscle strength, mass, fatigue, and metabolic markers in older men.
results_summary: The study found that soluble milk proteins rich in leucine (10 g/day) improved time to muscle failure, increased skeletal muscle mass and strength, and reduced body fat mass, insulin resistance, and blood creatine phosphokinase in older men undergoing exercise training.
population_specificity: 48 healthy sedentary men aged 60.8 ± 0.4 years.
effective_dosage: 10 g/day of soluble milk proteins rich in leucine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically evaluate the therapeutic potential of leucine in attenuating muscle wasting associated with ageing, cancer, and immobilization/bed rest, and to assess its impact on protein synthesis and muscle mass over time.
results_summary: The study found that while leucine acutely stimulates mTORC1 and protein synthesis, long-term supplementation does not enhance muscle mass or function in humans, and it is ineffective as a standalone intervention for preventing muscle wasting. The review also highlights the role of inflammation in diminishing leucine's efficacy.
population_specificity: Humans, particularly those with muscle wasting conditions (ageing, cancer, immobilization/bed rest).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether enteral supplementation with leucine-enriched essential amino acids (EAA) could limit muscle wasting in critically ill patients and other vulnerable groups with muscle wasting illnesses.
results_summary: The study found that leucine-enriched EAA demonstrated improvements in body composition and nutritional status in some muscle wasting illnesses, but methodological heterogeneity and varied study quality prevented firm conclusions. High-quality research is still needed in critical care settings.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients and other groups with muscle wasting illnesses (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, chronic heart failure, sarcopenia, disuse atrophy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent findings on the role of leucine in enhancing muscle protein synthesis (MPS) and hypertrophy following resistance training, and to discuss practical applications of these results.
results_summary: The study found that leucine, either as free L-leucine or in high-leucine whole proteins, enhances the initiation of translation necessary for increased MPS and muscle hypertrophy. However, the effects of different protein sources and timing protocols on MPS remain less understood.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on resistance-training individuals)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of leucine supplementation combined with moderate exercise to improve exercise capacity, muscle mass, and health-related quality of life in patients with cirrhosis.
results_summary: The study found that leucine supplementation combined with moderate exercise significantly improved exercise capacity, thigh circumference (indicating increased muscle mass), and several domains of health-related quality of life in patients with cirrhosis, with no observed complications.
population_specificity: Outpatients with cirrhosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with an aromatic amino acid (AAA) cocktail, including leucine, improved protein kinetics in children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) during catch-up growth and recovery phases.
results_summary: AAA supplementation significantly increased protein synthesis and improved protein balance at mid-catch-up growth and recovery compared to the control group (Ala).
population_specificity: Children aged 4-31 months with severe acute malnutrition (SAM).
effective_dosage: 330 mg · kg(-1) · d(-1) of AAA cocktail.
study_duration: From the end of the maintenance period (∼13 days postadmission) until full nutritional recovery (∼48 days postadmission).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the specific effect of leucine on mTORC1 signaling and amino acid metabolism in connection with resistance exercise, comparing supplements with and without leucine.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation significantly increased mTOR and p70S6k phosphorylation, suggesting enhanced protein synthesis, while reducing tyrosine and EAA levels in muscle and plasma. No significant changes were observed in MAFbx and MuRF-1 mRNA or protein levels.
population_specificity: Eight young women
effective_dosage: Small boluses of an aqueous solution of essential amino acids with or without leucine, given throughout the experiment (exact dosage not specified).
study_duration: Single session with measurements taken before exercise and 1 and 3 hours postexercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between the APOE p.Leu167del mutation (involving leucine deletion) and disorders like dyslipidemia and splenomegaly, including its phenotypic variability.
results_summary: The study identified a 3-generation kindred with the APOE p.Leu167del mutation, showing variable expression (splenomegaly and dyslipidemia in the proband but not in descendants). Aggressive lipid treatment appeared to improve splenomegaly in the proband.
population_specificity: Patients with dyslipidemia and splenomegaly, including a 76-year-old male proband and his descendants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary leucine, arginine, and protein levels on fat content, fatty acid composition, and lipid metabolism gene expression in pig muscle and adipose tissue.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation in a reduced protein diet did not change intramuscular fat, total fat in subcutaneous adipose tissue, or back fat thickness but altered fatty acid composition in muscle by increasing 16:0 and 18:1cis-9 and decreasing 18:2n-6.
population_specificity: Fifty-four intact male crossbred pigs (Duroc × Pietrain × Large White × Landrace) weighing 59–92 kg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of MCT oil and corn oil supplementation on TRL apo B-48 and VLDL apo B-100 kinetics and intestinal gene expression related to lipid metabolism.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between MCT and corn oil supplementation in plasma lipoprotein profiles, TRL apo B-48 and VLDL apo B-100 kinetics, or intestinal gene expression levels. Positive correlations in gene expression were observed in a subgroup after MCT supplementation, but no overall differences were detected.
population_specificity: 28 obese, insulin-resistant men
effective_dosage: 20 g MCT oil/day or 20 g corn oil/day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of whey protein isolate supplementation (containing leucine) on blood amino acid profiles and hormonal concentrations following a final meal.
results_summary: Whey protein supplementation significantly increased plasma levels of total amino acids, essential amino acids (EAA), branched-chain amino acids (BCAA), and leucine, but had no effect on glucose, insulin, testosterone, cortisol, or growth hormone.
population_specificity: Nine males aged 29.6 ± 6.3 years.
effective_dosage: 0.8 g·kg⁻¹·d⁻¹ (low-dose) and 1.6 g·kg⁻¹·d⁻¹ (high-dose) of whey protein isolate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether protein quality (fast-digesting vs. slow-digesting) influences the efficacy of optimal protein intake levels for protein retention in elderly men, with a focus on leucine availability.
results_summary: High-protein (HP) diets stimulated whole-body protein synthesis, and fast-digesting proteins (PRO) led to a better postprandial leucine balance compared to slow-digesting caseins (CAS). Net leucine balance was greater after HP meals, particularly with PRO supplementation.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly men (mean age 71.8 ± 24.4 years).
effective_dosage: 15 g or 30 g of protein (PRO or CAS) consumed every 20 minutes for 4 hours.
study_duration: 10-day dietary intervention with acute postprandial measurements over 4 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of leucine supplementation in limiting muscle mass loss during disuse and improving protein gain during recovery, particularly in aging populations.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that leucine supplementation, among other nutritional strategies, may help mitigate muscle atrophy during disuse and enhance recovery, though specific efficacy data are not detailed. The review highlights the potential of leucine but does not provide conclusive results.
population_specificity: Individuals experiencing muscle disuse due to pathologies, aging, or immobilization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whey protein (higher in leucine) promotes greater increases in muscle mass compared to soy protein or carbohydrate in non-resistance-trained individuals undergoing resistance training.
results_summary: Whey protein supplementation resulted in significantly greater lean body mass gains (3.3 kg) compared to soy (1.8 kg) and carbohydrate (2.3 kg). Fasting leucine concentrations were elevated by 20% in the whey group and positively correlated with lean body mass gains.
population_specificity: Non-resistance-trained men and women
effective_dosage: Daily isocaloric supplements (exact leucine dosage not specified; total protein intake was 1.4 g·kg⁻¹ for whey and soy groups)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the theoretical rationale for leucine supplementation in reducing muscle atrophy during injury recovery and immobilization.
results_summary: The study suggests leucine may help reduce muscle atrophy during immobilization, but it primarily provides a theoretical rationale rather than empirical results. Rehabilitation and recovery require increased protein intake and resistance exercise to restore muscle protein synthesis.
population_specificity: Individuals recovering from injuries involving limb immobilization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether liver-targeted androgen supplementation (via oral testosterone) induces protein anabolism in GH-replete normal women by assessing leucine turnover and related metabolic effects.
results_summary: Testosterone treatment significantly reduced leucine rate of appearance (protein breakdown) by 7.1% and leucine oxidation (irreversible protein loss) by 14.6%, while increasing IGF1 levels without systemic androgen excess or adverse liver effects.
population_specificity: Eight healthy postmenopausal women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of leucine supplementation on muscle strength recovery in athletes undergoing rehabilitation after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.
results_summary: Both groups showed improved muscle quality, but the leucine group had a significant improvement in thigh muscle perimeter at 10cm from the patella. Other muscle parameters did not show significant differences between the leucine and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Athletes undergoing rehabilitation after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ligamentoplasty).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate molecular and metabolic changes, including leucine levels, following n-3 PUFA supplementation in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found that n-3 PUFA supplementation increased leucine levels in men but did not report changes in women. Metabolomic profiles indicated gender-specific metabolic responses.
population_specificity: Healthy men (13) and women (17)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of bioenhanced whey protein (with additional PEG leucine) versus standard whey protein or placebo on muscle performance, size, and blood markers during resistance training.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in muscle strength, endurance, body composition, or muscle cross-sectional area between groups, regardless of supplementation. However, the bioenhanced whey protein groups showed a higher Albumin:Globulin ratio compared to the standard whey protein group.
population_specificity: Healthy, recreationally trained, college-aged men (n = 106).
effective_dosage: 5 g of additional polyethylene glycosylated (PEG) leucine per shake, consumed twice on training days and once on non-training days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of an 8-week lysine supplementation diet on muscle mass and function in undernourished and well-nourished men.
results_summary: The high lysine diet (80 mg/kg/day) had a small positive effect (+7.5%) on muscle strength but no significant impact on other parameters like muscle mass or insulin sensitivity. Changes in muscle strength correlated with changes in muscle mass, and muscle mass changes correlated with insulin sensitivity changes, but no intake-specific differences were observed.
population_specificity: Healthy, undernourished, and well-nourished men.
effective_dosage: Low lysine diets (~25 mg/kg/day for undernourished, ~40 mg/kg/day for well-nourished) and high lysine diet (80 mg/kg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of leucine-enriched essential amino acid protein supplements in treating sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study suggests that leucine-enriched essential amino acid protein supplements, combined with resistance exercise, are effective in addressing sarcopenia. The abstract also highlights emerging potential for other treatments like testosterone and an activin II receptor soluble fusion protein.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with age-related muscle loss (sarcopenia).

study_goal: The researchers explored whether leucine supplementation could ameliorate impaired translation due to ribosomal insufficiency in Diamond Blackfan anemia (DBA).
results_summary: The abstract suggests leucine supplementation may help address ribosomal insufficiency in DBA, but the molecular basis for steroid responsiveness in DBA remains unknown. Further investigation is warranted.
population_specificity: Patients with Diamond Blackfan anemia (DBA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of leucine in regulating human myofibrillar protein synthesis (MPS) and its effectiveness compared to other amino acid formulations.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation was as effective as complete whey protein in stimulating postprandial MPS, but only whey protein sustained increased MPS rates post-exercise. No significant differences in MPS were observed between leucine and other essential amino acid formulations during early post-exercise periods.
population_specificity: 24 males
effective_dosage: 6.25 g whey protein with leucine equivalent to 25 g whey protein

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether leucine-rich amino acid supplementation, alone or combined with exercise, enhances muscle mass and strength in elderly sarcopenic women.
results_summary: The study found that combining exercise with leucine-rich amino acid supplementation significantly improved leg muscle mass, walking speed, and knee extension strength, with the greatest benefits seen in the combined intervention group.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling elderly sarcopenic women aged 75 and older in Tokyo, Japan.
effective_dosage: 3 g of a leucine-rich essential amino acid mixture twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine leucine's role as a pharmaconutrient in preventing and treating sarcopenia and type 2 diabetes by examining its effects on muscle protein synthesis and insulin secretion.
results_summary: The study found that leucine upregulates mRNA translation, increasing muscle protein synthesis and net muscle protein accretion, particularly in the elderly. Short-term studies suggest leucine supplementation can stimulate muscle mass accretion, but long-term benefits remain unconfirmed.
population_specificity: Elderly humans (specific age range not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of enteral leucine infusion on the whole proteome of duodenal mucosa in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation altered the duodenal mucosal proteome, regulating the expression of enzymes involved in lipid metabolism, including reduced expression of HADHA, ACADVL, and CPT2, and increased expression of FABP1. The results suggest leucine may slow fatty acid beta-oxidation in human duodenal mucosa.
population_specificity: 5 healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 0.035 g kg(-1) h(-1) leucine supplemented with maltodextrins

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplemental leucine uniquely stimulates muscle protein synthesis (MPS) in humans compared to other essential amino acids (EAAs).
results_summary: The study found no improvement in resting MPS in adults consuming a 10 g EAA supplement with added leucine (3.5 g) compared to a control EAA supplement (1.8 g leucine), suggesting added leucine is unnecessary for MPS stimulation when sufficient EAAs are provided. Further research on leucine's effects during endurance exercise, caloric deprivation, and ageing may be warranted.
population_specificity: Adults
effective_dosage: 10 g EAA supplement (3.5 g leucine vs. 1.8 g leucine)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of postexercise protein-leucine coingestion with CHO-lipid on high-intensity endurance performance and investigate mechanisms using stable isotope methods and metabolomics.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation increased BCAA levels and metabolism, saturated BCAA metabolism, and attenuated tissue damage, but had trivial effects on sprint power and endurance performance under positive nitrogen balance conditions.
population_specificity: 12 male cyclists

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of leucine-enriched balanced amino acids in enhancing muscle strength as part of nutritional recommendations for sarcopenia prevention and management.
results_summary: The study found that adequate protein intake, including leucine-enriched balanced amino acids, may enhance muscle strength, though protein supplementation alone only slows muscle mass loss. Combining exercise with adequate protein and energy intake is key for sarcopenia management.
population_specificity: Individuals at risk for or experiencing sarcopenia, cachexia, or wasting diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if daily oral L-leucine supplementation enhances strength, lean tissue mass, and fat mass during a 12-week resistance training program in untrained men.
results_summary: The leucine group showed significantly greater strength gains (40.8% vs. 31.0%) compared to placebo, but no significant differences were found in lean tissue mass or fat mass changes between groups.
population_specificity: Initially untrained men (age ~28.5 years, BMI ~24.9 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whey-protein and leucine supplementation could enhance physical and cognitive performance and body composition in moderately fit individuals.
results_summary: The study found that leucine supplementation significantly improved bench-press and push-up performance, as well as increased total mass, fat-free mass, and lean body mass, but showed no effect on crunches, chin-ups, 3-mile-run time, or cognitive performance.
population_specificity: Thirty moderately fit participants.
effective_dosage: 6.2 g leucine daily (combined with 19.7 g whey protein).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dietary leucine or leucine-rich mixtures on muscle protein synthesis, lean body mass, and weight management in various conditions.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation increased plasma leucine levels and muscle protein synthesis, but long-term supplementation alone did not significantly improve lean body mass or muscle mass during resistance training or in the elderly. Leucine-rich amino acid mixtures or proteins were more effective than leucine alone for improving muscle mass and performance.
population_specificity: Elderly, individuals undergoing resistance training, malnourished patients, and obese patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Licorice (GC) could protect against cisplatin-induced hepatotoxicity in rats and elucidate its mechanisms related to ER stress and apoptosis.
results_summary: Licorice significantly improved liver function, reduced liver lesions, decreased oxidative stress, and inhibited ER stress and apoptosis markers in cisplatin-induced hepatotoxicity in rats. The study demonstrated Licorice's protective effects via the PERK/ATF4/CHOP pathway.
population_specificity: Rats with cisplatin-induced liver injury and LO2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the theoretical rationale for leucine supplementation in reducing muscle atrophy during immobilization and recovery.
results_summary: The study suggests a theoretical basis for leucine supplementation to help mitigate muscle atrophy during immobilization, but it does not provide empirical data or clinical results. During rehabilitation, increased activity and proper nutrition, including protein and energy intake, are emphasized for muscle growth.
population_specificity: Individuals experiencing limb immobilization due to injuries and those in rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active components and mechanisms of Licorice (GC) in mitigating cisplatin-induced liver injury, focusing on bile acid metabolism and gut microbiota regulation.
results_summary: Licorice significantly reduced liver function biomarkers, improved liver tissue pathology, and regulated bile acid metabolism and gut microbiota balance. Sixteen blood-entering components were identified as potential pharmacodynamic agents.
population_specificity: Rats with cisplatin-induced liver injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explain the mechanisms by which Glycyrrhiza uralensis (GU) reconciles medicine in Huanggui Shaogan decoction (HSGD) and its role in improving the treatment of oxaliplatin-induced peripheral neuropathy (OIPN).
results_summary: The study identified 22 differential chemical components in HSGD, including flavonoids and saponins, and demonstrated that HSGD improved pain thresholds, reduced hypersensitivity, and alleviated neuronal injury in OIPN. GU enhanced the solubilization of certain components and improved the overall efficacy of the treatment.
population_specificity: Murine model of oxaliplatin-induced peripheral neuropathy (OIPN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of licorice extract as an inhibitor in a "germination-inactivation-inhibition" strategy for deactivating Paraclostridium bifermentans spores.
results_summary: Licorice extract (6.25 mg/mL) facilitated spore dispersion, exacerbated thermosonication-induced inner membrane damage and nucleic acid leakage, and inhibited the growth of remaining spores, achieving a 99.97% spore inactivation rate.
population_specificity: Paraclostridium bifermentans spores in a laboratory setting.
study_duration: Not specified (single application during the experiment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether licorice root extract (LRE) combined with melatonin could mitigate cadmium and salinity-induced stress in faba bean plants by improving physiological and biochemical responses.
results_summary: LRE + melatonin significantly reduced oxidative damage, improved antioxidant enzyme activity, and enhanced osmolyte content, mitigating cadmium-induced stress in faba bean plants. The combination also reduced cadmium accumulation in leaves and seeds while improving growth and yield-related traits.
population_specificity: Faba bean (Vicia faba L.) plants grown in cadmium-contaminated saline soil.
effective_dosage: 3% licorice root extract (LRE) applied as a foliar spray.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of leucine supplementation on skeletal muscle structure and function in atrophic conditions such as muscle disuse, sarcopenia, and cancer.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation showed remarkable effects on muscle remodeling through protein turnover modulation, potentially improving physiological parameters related to muscle function and quality of life. It may mitigate the atrophic effects of catabolic conditions.
population_specificity: Individuals with atrophic conditions (muscle disuse, sarcopenia, cancer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the historical and modern evidence supporting licorice's efficacy in treating traumatic injuries and its current clinical perception.
results_summary: The study found that licorice was historically used for traumatic injuries, supported by modern pharmacological evidence, but its current clinical use primarily focuses on its role as a "harmonizing" agent, overlooking its potential for trauma treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (historical and modern pharmacological context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antimicrobial efficacy of ethanolic and aqueous licorice extracts against the periodontal pathogen Prevotella intermedia.
results_summary: Licorice extract demonstrated antimicrobial activity against P. intermedia, with the ethanolic extract showing significantly stronger effects (MIC 0.1%) than the aqueous extract (MIC 0.8%). The ethanolic extract was comparable to chlorhexidine, suggesting its potential as an alternative.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study targeting P. intermedia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gargling with licorice reduces postoperative pain and morphine consumption in patients undergoing oropharyngeal surgery.
results_summary: Licorice gargling did not significantly reduce postoperative pain or morphine consumption compared to placebo. The study found noninferiority in pain scores but no superiority in either pain reduction or morphine consumption.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing elective oropharyngeal surgery.
effective_dosage: 1 g licorice before and up to three days after surgery.
study_duration: Before surgery and for up to three days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Licorice (GC) influences the gut-joint axis to reduce rheumatoid arthritis (RA) symptoms by examining its effects on intestinal barrier integrity, gut microbiota, and immune cell balance.
results_summary: Licorice significantly improved joint inflammation markers, intestinal barrier function, and Th17/Treg cell ratios while modifying gut flora and metabolites linked to RA. Fecal microbiota transplantation confirmed the role of gut microbiota in GC-mediated RA therapy.
population_specificity: Bovine type-II collagen-induced arthritis rat model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the dynamic evolution of licorice seed germination states under different salt stress conditions using an optimized detection model.
results_summary: The study found that licorice seeds exhibited varying germination states (unsprouted, sprouted, cracked, shelled) under different NaCl concentrations, with distinct percentage trends for each state. The YOLOv8-Licorice model effectively detected these germination states, providing a method to analyze seed sprouting under stress.
population_specificity: Licorice seeds under controlled salt stress conditions.
effective_dosage: Not specified (NaCl concentrations ranged from 0-300 mmol/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different irrigation levels and seaweed extract (SWE) concentrations affect glycyrrhizic acid content, glabridin content, and enzyme activity in licorice plants under drought stress.
results_summary: The study found that glycyrrhizic acid content increased with water stress intensity, and SWE application (10 g/L) further enhanced this effect under optimal irrigation. Glabridin content peaked under severe water stress with SWE application. Enzyme activities (APX, CAT, POD, SOD) also increased with water stress and were further boosted by SWE.
population_specificity: One-year-old licorice (Glycyrrhiza glabra L.) plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-obesity and hepatoprotective effects of Glycyrrhiza glabra (licorice) extract in rats with diet-induced obesity and hyperlipidemia.
results_summary: Glycyrrhiza glabra extract significantly reduced body weight gain in obese rats and improved liver histology, showing protective effects against fat deposits, degeneration, and necrosis. It also ameliorated serum levels of liver enzymes (ALT, AST, ALP, LDH) and lipid profiles (HDL, LDL, triglycerides).
population_specificity: Wistar albino rats with diet-induced obesity and hyperlipidemia.
effective_dosage: 1g/kg body weight daily via orogastric gavage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) on the growth dynamics, root configuration, and metabolites of licorice under saline-alkali conditions.
results_summary: The study found that AMF significantly increased licorice root growth and biomass, with 978 metabolites detected, showing significant changes in differential metabolites under AMF treatment. Metabolic pathways and biosynthesis of secondary metabolites were enriched in the early period, while microbial metabolism and aromatic compound degradation were prominent later.
population_specificity: Licorice plants grown in saline-alkali soil conditions.
study_duration: 45 days (with samples taken at 15 and 45 days)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of D-reglis® (licorice root extract) as an adjuvant therapy in reducing ICU stay and improving outcomes in critically ill COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The licorice group had a significantly shorter ICU stay compared to the placebo group, but no significant differences were observed in oxygen saturation, SOFA score, duration of mechanical ventilation, or mortality rate.
population_specificity: Critically ill COVID-19 patients in the ICU.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal concentration of GR24 (a synthetic strigolactone) for promoting licorice growth and development under varying phosphorus conditions.
results_summary: The study found that GR24 at 10 µM (G3) enhanced growth metrics, chlorophyll levels, and antioxidant enzyme activities under high (P3) and low (P2) phosphorus conditions. It also increased specific bioactive compounds (e.g., liquiritigenin, glycyrrhizic acid) under P3 and isoliquiritigenin, liquiritigenin, and liquiritin under P2, while transcriptome analysis revealed differential gene expression linked to phosphorus response.
population_specificity: Ural Glycyrrhiza uralensis Fisch (a licorice species) under controlled phosphorus conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of licorice formulations, alone or in combination with other herbs, on liver function enzymes in patients with primary liver disease.
results_summary: Licorice significantly reduced ALT and AST levels compared to control groups, with purified glycyrrhizic acid compounds showing the greatest effect. While it did not significantly impact gamma-glutamyl transferase and total bilirubin overall, specific licorice-herb preparations reduced TBIL. The safety profile was consistent with known mild mineralocorticoid-related side effects.
population_specificity: Patients with primary liver disease (1367 participants across 15 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how licorice processing of different Evodiae Fructus specifications affects liver inflammation, oxidative stress, and intestinal mucosal microbiota in mice.
results_summary: Licorice processing reduced oxidative stress and inflammatory effects compared to raw Evodiae Fructus, modulated gut microbiota (e.g., enriching probiotics like Lactobacillus), and brought metabolic function closer to control levels. Medium-flowered Evodiae Fructus had stronger effects on liver inflammation and oxidative stress than small-flowered, but licorice processing mitigated this difference.
population_specificity: 25 Kunming mice divided into control and intervention groups.
effective_dosage: Not specified (EF extract solutions administered by gavage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antibacterial efficacy of licorice gel versus tetracycline gel against periodontal pathogens (Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Porphyromonas gingivalis, and Prevotella intermedia).
results_summary: Licorice gel showed higher drug release and significant antibacterial activity against A. actinomycetemcomitans compared to tetracycline gel, though tetracycline was more effective against P. gingivalis and P. intermedia. Licorice gel demonstrated antimicrobial properties at low concentrations, suggesting potential as an adjunctive treatment for periodontal disease.
population_specificity: In vitro study (bacterial cultures, not human subjects).
study_duration: Not specified (single-time measurement of inhibition zones after 24-hour incubation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to increase awareness about licorice-induced pseudohyperaldosteronism (PHA) and its risks associated with excessive intake.
results_summary: The study found that excessive licorice intake can cause PHA, characterized by hypertension and hypokalemia, due to glycyrrhetinic acid's action on mineralocorticoid receptors. Symptoms typically resolve after licorice withdrawal, but severe cases may require treatment with MR blockers and potassium supplements.
population_specificity: Patients with hypertension and hypokalemia, particularly those consuming licorice products.
interactions: Increased risk in patients with comorbidities or those taking interfering drugs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review experimental studies on the effects and potential mechanisms of licorice chalcones in nicotine-induced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) treatment.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that licorice chalcones exhibit pharmacological effects, including anticancer properties, but the specific mechanisms in nicotine-induced NSCLC remain unknown. The study reviews existing experimental data but does not present new findings.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and/or in vivo experiments mentioned, but no human population detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether licorice root extract, either pure or encapsulated in nanoliposomes and coated with chitosan, could improve shrimp shelf life and prevent browning during ice storage.
results_summary: Licorice root extract (LHE) significantly reduced browning indices, TBA, and FFA in shrimp. Chitosan-coated LHE showed the best performance for TVN, microbial counts, and discoloration, while chitosan-coated LHE nanoliposomes maintained acceptable levels of PV, WHC, and cook loss.
population_specificity: Shrimp (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer efficacy of Glycyrrhizic Acid (GA) and Licorice extract (Lic) encapsulated in Polyethylene Glycol Liposomes (PEG-Lip) against human gastric (AGS) and prostate (PC-3) cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that GA and Lic encapsulated in PEG-Lip exhibited enhanced cytotoxic effects, with GA PEG-Lip reducing cell viability by 12.5% (PC-3) and 15.9% (AGS). Apoptosis assays confirmed stronger apoptotic effects compared to free GA and Lic.
population_specificity: Human gastric cancer (AGS) and prostate cancer (PC-3) cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of licorice root aqueous extract in mitigating and detoxifying the toxic effects of glyphosate-based pesticides on kidney, liver, thyroid functions, and apoptosis in rats.
results_summary: Licorice root aqueous extract (300 mg/mL) significantly reduced liver and kidney enzyme levels, albumin, and AFP levels in serum, and demonstrated dose-dependent attenuation of apoptosis and inflammation. The study suggests licorice may offer a sustainable approach to counteracting glyphosate toxicity in agricultural practices.
population_specificity: 50 adult male albino rats divided into 5 groups of 10 each.
effective_dosage: 100, 200, and 300 mg/mL distilled water, administered daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of licorice mouthwash versus chlorhexidine mouthwash on the oral health of intubated patients in an intensive care setting.
results_summary: Licorice mouthwash significantly improved oral health in intubated patients, with effects comparable to chlorhexidine, though chlorhexidine showed slightly greater impact on plaque reduction and saliva thinning. No significant difference in overall oral health outcomes was found between the two groups post-intervention.
population_specificity: Intubated patients admitted to an intensive care unit in Iran.
effective_dosage: 20% licorice mouthwash applied twice daily (15 ml per use).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-colorectal cancer effect and underlying mechanism of wighteone, a prenylated flavonoid in licorice.
results_summary: Wighteone inhibited Akt phosphorylation, leading to reduced cell viability, cycle arrest, apoptosis, and autophagic death in SW480 colorectal cancer cells, and demonstrated in vivo anti-tumor effects in a mouse model.
population_specificity: SW480 human colorectal cancer cells and nude mouse xenograft model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the key cardioprotective components of honey-processed licorice (HPL) and predict its mechanism of action against doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.
results_summary: Six differential compounds were identified as key cardioprotective components of HPL, with five (liquiritin, isoliquiritin, liquiritigenin, isoliquiritigenin, and licochalcone A) showing significant protective effects against oxidative stress and mitochondrial damage in an in vitro model of doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity. Network pharmacology and molecular docking suggested the PI3K-Akt pathway and Nrf2 protein as potential mechanisms.
population_specificity: In vitro study using H9c2 cells (rat cardiomyocytes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which Licorice flavonoid (LF) protects against ethanol-induced gastric ulcers, focusing on metabolic pathways and apoptosis suppression.
results_summary: LF showed a positive impact on gastric injury, regulated GU-related factors, and activated the PI3K/AKT pathway to reduce apoptosis. Metabolomics identified 25 biomarkers linked to amino acid and carbohydrate metabolism, with six key targets (HSP90AA1, AKT1, MAPK1, EGFR, ESR1, PIK3CA) implicated in the anti-GU effects.
population_specificity: Ethanol-induced gastric injury rat model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the key genes and pathways responsible for the differences in salt tolerance between Glycyrrhiza inflata and Glycyrrhiza uralensis to cultivate high-quality salt-tolerant licorice varieties.
results_summary: G. inflata demonstrated greater salt tolerance than G. uralensis, maintaining stable biomass and flavonoid accumulation, restricting Na+ to roots, and accumulating more K+ and Ca2+. Transcriptome analysis linked these traits to carbon metabolism, ion transport, antioxidant biosynthesis, and regulatory pathways.
population_specificity: Glycyrrhiza inflata and Glycyrrhiza uralensis plants (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (salt treatment applied, but exact dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Measurements taken at 0.5 d, 15 d, and 30 d.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether isoliquiritigenin (ISL) from licorice could ameliorate endothelial dysfunction in type 2 diabetes (T2D) by reducing oxidative stress and inflammation.
results_summary: ISL significantly improved endothelial function in T2D mice by reducing ROS levels and pro-inflammatory factors (MCP-1, TNF-α, IL-6) while restoring anti-inflammatory and antioxidant markers (IL-10, SOD1, Nrf2, HO-1). The study suggests ISL as a potential therapeutic agent for vascular diseases.
population_specificity: db/db male mice (T2D model) and mouse brain microvascular endothelial cells (mBMECs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of licorice in treating ulcerative colitis (UC) and experimentally verify its activity, focusing on the Nrf2/PINK1 signaling pathway.
results_summary: Licorice improved colon histopathology, reduced inflammatory markers (IL-6, IL-17), repaired mitochondrial damage, and activated autophagy via the Nrf2/PINK1 pathway, demonstrating anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects in UC models.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice with UC induced by DSS and LPS-treated Caco2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to formulate and characterize licorice extract nanoemulsions and compare their efficacy against coronavirus for potential subcutaneous injection.
results_summary: The licorice extract nanoemulsion exhibited better release and physical stability compared to remdesivir nanoemulsion, suggesting potential as a subcutaneous injection for mild to moderate coronavirus. The optimal formulation (F7) showed favorable physicochemical properties, including droplet size, polydispersity index, and zeta potential.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).
