study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ultrasound-assisted vacuum drying (UAVD) in improving the drying efficiency and quality of licorice extract, focusing on water mobility, bioactive compound retention, and antioxidant capacity.
results_summary: UAVD reduced drying times by 9.09-69.70% and preserved key bioactive compounds (liquiritin and glycyrrhizic acid) at 80 W, while maintaining high antioxidant activity (DPPH inhibition rates of 84.07-90.65%). High ultrasonic power also improved water flow and porous structure formation.
population_specificity: Licorice extract (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a sustainable licorice-based hydrogel treatment for oral traumatic ulcers and evaluate its effects on wound healing and inflammation.
results_summary: Licorice-based hydrogels (LHGs) with higher concentrations of licorice extract (30%) and HEC (4%) significantly enhanced wound healing, increased growth factor expression (EGF by 66.67%, VEGF by 23.24%), and reduced inflammation by 88% compared to controls. The formulations also exhibited desirable rheological properties for prolonged residence time.
population_specificity: Oral traumatic ulcer patients (specific human or animal model not specified in abstract).
effective_dosage: 30% dried licorice root extract and 4% HEC in hydrogel formulation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism of Licorice rose beverage (LRB) in treating melasma using network pharmacology and experimental techniques.
results_summary: LRB significantly inhibited tyrosinase activity in vitro and improved skin damage, pigmentation, and oxidative stress markers in mice, demonstrating anti-melasma effects. Key active components (Isolicoflavonol, quercetin, kaempferol) showed strong target affinity.
population_specificity: Model mice with induced melasma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the DNA methylation inhibitor 5-azacitidine (5-azaC) could enhance the production of Licochalcone A (LCA) in Glycyrrhiza inflata.
results_summary: The study found that 5-azaC treatment successfully increased LCA content in G. inflata seedlings, field plants, and hairy roots, likely by stimulating gene expression rather than altering DNA methylation. Transcriptome analysis identified differentially expressed genes related to flavonoid biosynthesis, but DNA methylation changes were minimal.
population_specificity: Glycyrrhiza inflata (licorice) seedlings, field plants, and hairy roots.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active ingredients, drug targets, and therapeutic mechanisms of bitter almond-licorice in treating COVID-19.
results_summary: The study found that bitter almond-licorice had 89 active components targeting 102 potential COVID-19-related genes, with key targets including IL-6, TNF, MAPK1, and IL1B, suggesting anti-inflammatory effects through pathways like TNF and IL-17 signaling. Molecular docking confirmed the binding affinity of active components to therapeutic targets.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico study using databases and molecular docking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic benefits of licorice extracts and their bioactive components for treating common oral diseases.
results_summary: Licorice showed potential in inhibiting viruses, preventing biofilm formation, reducing inflammation, boosting immune responses, alleviating pain, and exerting antioxidative effects. Its bioactive compounds demonstrated anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, antioxidative, and immunomodulatory properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular basis of flavonoid and triterpene biosynthesis in licorice under drought conditions using multi-omics analysis.
results_summary: The study found that drought stress upregulated key genes and proteins involved in flavonoid and glycyrrhizin biosynthesis, suggesting that drought may enhance the accumulation of bioactive compounds in licorice.
population_specificity: Licorice plants (Glycyrrhiza species) under drought conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of topical licorice (Glycyrrhiza glabra) on recurrent aphthous stomatitis (RAS) management, focusing on pain reduction, ulcer size, and healing time.
results_summary: Licorice significantly reduced RAS pain, ulcer size, and healing time, with effectiveness linked to its anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antibacterial properties. It also elevated epidermal growth factor (EGF) levels, enhancing oral mucosal tissue integrity, and showed no adverse effects.
population_specificity: 314 subjects with recurrent aphthous stomatitis (RAS).
effective_dosage: 1% or 5% concentrations in various forms (paste, patch, mouthwash).
study_duration: Healing time expected within 4-8 days (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of licorice extract (glycyrrhizin) in treating moderate COVID-19 by assessing clinical symptoms and safety outcomes.
results_summary: Licorice showed no significant improvement in SPO2, body temperature, or respiratory rate compared to the control group, but CRP and ALT levels improved toward baseline. The intervention demonstrated a safe profile with no significant differences in adverse events, mortality, or hospital stay length.
population_specificity: 60 patients with confirmed moderate COVID-19.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanism by which Licorice flavonoid (LF) exerts its anti-gastric ulcer effects, focusing on inflammation, mucosal barrier repair, gut microbiota modulation, and the EGFR/ERK pathway.
results_summary: LF increased gastric mucosal cell viability, reduced ethanol-induced injury and inflammation, restored the gastric mucosal barrier, modulated gut dysbiosis, and upregulated SCFAs, which boosted mucus secretion and activated the EGFR/ERK pathway to promote gastric mucus cell regeneration.
population_specificity: GU rats and human gastric mucosal epithelial (GES-1) cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the metabolism features and anti-COVID-19 mechanisms of the Radix Scutellaria-Licorice drug pair (RSLDP) using a novel target network pharmacology (T-NP) approach.
results_summary: The study identified 85 absorbed constituents in rat plasma, with compatibility increasing the number of active components. RSLDP targeted 106 potential COVID-19-related pathways, including inflammatory and immune responses, suggesting its therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether licorice-saponin A3 (A3) could inhibit SARS-CoV-2 variants and modulate host inflammation pathways.
results_summary: A3 broadly inhibited SARS-CoV-2 variants (Beta, Delta, Omicron BA.1, XBB, BQ1.1) with an EC50 of 1.016 μM and reduced inflammation by modulating JNK and p38 MAPK pathways.
population_specificity: In vitro (Vero E6 cells) and molecular analysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a hybrid wastewater treatment system for processing liquorice root extract wastewater to make it suitable for agricultural reuse.
results_summary: The hybrid biological and post-biological treatment system achieved 86-98% reduction in pollutants (COD, BOD5, TSS, etc.), though colour removal required additional processes (biodegradation-lime-alum-ozonation) to reach 98% efficiency. The treated wastewater was deemed suitable for crop irrigation.
population_specificity: Wastewater from liquorice root extract processing

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the bioactive compounds in licorice extract and evaluate its beneficial effects in periodontal therapy.
results_summary: The study found that licorice extract contains bioactive compounds with anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and anti-adherence effects, which are beneficial against periodontal disease. Clinical trials and literature review support its dual functionality in addressing host response and microorganisms involved in periodontal disease.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontal disease (specific population details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of licorice essential oil as an alternative to chemical antibiotics in broiler production, focusing on health, safety, and biochemical effects.
results_summary: Licorice essential oil did not significantly affect body weight, feed intake, or feed conversion ratio but reduced gallbladder relative weight (0.1%) and abdominal fat (0.3%). Blood glucose, cholesterol, and LDL levels decreased significantly, and a humoral immune response improvement was noted at 0.1%.
population_specificity: Day-old broiler chicks (160 total, divided into four treatment groups).
effective_dosage: 0.1%, 0.2%, and 0.3% licorice essential oil in elemental diet.
study_duration: Three-phase feeding schedule (starter, grower, finisher diet; exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardio-protective effects of honey-processed licorice (HPL) and explore the distribution of its main components in vivo under normal and pathological conditions to clarify its pharmacological basis for treating arrhythmia.
results_summary: HPL ameliorated heart injury and bradycardia induced by doxorubicin (DOX) by increasing SOD activity and reducing MDA content. The study found higher concentrations of liquiritin, isoliquiritin, and isoliquiritigenin in the heart under pathological conditions, suggesting these components may contribute to HPL's anti-arrhythmic effects.
population_specificity: Adult zebrafish with induced arrhythmia via DOX.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether licorice extract could inhibit the cGAS-STING pathway and improve hepatic inflammation and fibrosis in NASH mice models.
results_summary: Licorice extract inhibited cGAS-STING pathway activation, reduced inflammation and fibrosis in NASH mice, and showed similar therapeutic effects to a known STING inhibitor (C-176) when used alone or in combination.
population_specificity: Mice with methionine and choline-deficient diet (MCD)-induced NASH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify active compounds and targets in licorice that could be effective against COVID-19 using a deep learning-based network pharmacology approach.
results_summary: The study predicted and validated 4 known compounds (quercetin, naringenin, liquiritigenin, licoisoflavanone) and 2 new compounds (glabrone, vestitol) in licorice that bind well to COVID-19-related targets (Mpro, S-protein, ACE2, PTEN, MAP3K8), suggesting potential antiviral and anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Licorice flavonoids (LFs) could inhibit the cGAS-STING pathway and improve inflammatory conditions, specifically acute lung injury.
results_summary: LFs inhibited the cGAS-STING pathway, reducing expression of type I interferons, downstream genes (ISG15, CXCL10), and inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, TNF-α). LFs also improved LPS-induced acute lung injury by blocking excessive cGAS-STING activation.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or animal model based on abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antifungal efficacy of licorice (Glycyrrhiza glabra) cold water extract (LAE) against fungal pathogens affecting Capsicum annuum L. and explore its synergistic effects with thyme essential oil (TO).
results_summary: LAE at 200 mg ml-1 showed 89.9% antifungal activity against P. aphanidermatum, and when combined with TO at lower doses (100 mg ml-1 LAE and 0.125 mg ml-1 TO), it exhibited synergistic effects. The study attributed these effects to bioactive compounds in LAE and TO, which damaged fungal cell walls and reduced ergosterol biosynthesis.
population_specificity: Fungal pathogens (Colletotrichum capsici, Pythium aphanidermatum, Fusarium oxysporum) affecting Capsicum annuum L.
effective_dosage: 200 mg ml-1 (LAE alone), 100 mg ml-1 (LAE in combination)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the risks of excessive licorice consumption, particularly its mineralocorticoid-like effects leading to apparent mineralocorticoid excess (AME).
results_summary: The study found that excessive licorice consumption caused hypertension, edema, hypokalemia, and low aldosterone levels due to glycyrrhizic acid's inhibition of 11-β-HSD type 2, leading to sodium retention and potassium excretion. The case underscores the need for awareness and regulation of licorice intake.
population_specificity: A 49-year-old female patient consuming excessive licorice herbal teas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hydroalcoholic extract of licorice root accelerates wound healing in second-degree burns compared to a control hydrogel.
results_summary: The licorice hydrogel significantly reduced inflammation, redness, pain, and burning while accelerating the healing process compared to the control group, with statistically significant improvements observed from day 3 onward.
population_specificity: 50 patients with second-degree burns from Yazd Hospital and Isfahan Hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the molecular mechanism of the antioxidant effects of Licorice flavonoids (LCFs) and identify key active components.
results_summary: The study found that kumatakenin, licoflavonol, and topazolin in LCF are key antioxidant components with good biosafety. Molecular docking and dynamics simulations showed these molecules form stable complexes with target proteins, and their antioxidant activity is modulated by solvent-mediated effects, with higher pKa values enhancing activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and computational study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of noscapine plus licorice (Noscough® syrup) on relieving cough and dyspnea in COVID-19 outpatients compared to diphenhydramine.
results_summary: Noscapine plus licorice was slightly superior to diphenhydramine in relieving cough symptoms and dyspnea, with significantly better cough-related quality of life and severity scores. However, the overall treatment response rate difference was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: COVID-19 outpatients over 18 years of age with confirmed infection and cough symptoms lasting less than 5 days.
effective_dosage: Noscough® syrup 20 mL every 6 hours for 5 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether licorice could reduce inflammation and oxidative stress in ulcerative colitis (UC) by promoting mitochondrial autophagy via the Nrf2/PINK1 pathway.
results_summary: Licorice improved UC pathology in mice, reduced inflammatory cytokines and oxidative stress markers, and enhanced mitochondrial autophagy by upregulating Nrf2, PINK1, Parkin, HO-1, P62, and LC3 expression.
population_specificity: BALB/C mice with dextran sodium sulfate-induced ulcerative colitis.
effective_dosage: Different doses (specific amounts not stated) administered for 7 days.
study_duration: 7 days of licorice intervention after 7 days of UC modeling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of licorice vaginal cream and estrogen vaginal cream on sexual function in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Licorice vaginal cream improved sexual function scores from 17.86 to 20.31, but estrogen cream showed a greater improvement (17.14 to 22.97). The difference between the two treatments was statistically significant (p = 0.015).
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women in Ilam, Iran.
effective_dosage: 2% licorice vaginal cream, applied for 14-day periods.
study_duration: 14-day periods, with follow-up assessments at one and two months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether licorice zinc could inhibit melanogenesis and reduce pigmentation by affecting the JNK/p38 MAPK signaling pathway, suggesting its potential as an anti-chloasma agent.
results_summary: Licorice zinc reduced melanin formation, cutaneous tissue injury, and phosphorylation of JNK and P38MAPK in UVB-irradiated mice. In vitro, it decreased tyrosinase-related protein-1, tyrosinase, and microphthalmia-associated transcription factor, showing inhibitory effects on melanogenesis.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice with induced chloasma-like pigmentation.
effective_dosage: 0.65, 1.3, and 2.6 g/kg daily by oral administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ethanolic extract of licorice root (EELR) could effectively reduce benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)-induced lesions and improve biochemical and hormonal factors in dogs.
results_summary: The study found that EELR positively affected serum biochemical indices and hormone levels, reduced prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels, and decreased BPH-induced lesions without reported side effects.
population_specificity: 30 dogs of similar age and weight, divided into 6 groups (5 dogs each), including both non-neutered and neutered older dogs with BPH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether licorice gargle juice reduces pain and healing time in patients with aphthous ulcers.
results_summary: Licorice gargle juice significantly reduced pain levels compared to placebo at day 1 and day 2, as measured by a visual analog scale (VAS). The study suggests licorice gargle juice can rapidly alleviate pain and improve healing in aphthous ulcer patients.
population_specificity: Primary care patients suffering from aphthous ulcers (30 in intervention group, 24 in placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether echinatin, a bioactive component of licorice, could prevent paroxetine-induced liver injury by inhibiting inflammasome activation.
results_summary: Echinatin effectively blocked paroxetine-induced inflammasome activation, reduced TNF-α production, and reversed liver injury in an LPS-mediated model. Multiple licorice components also showed inhibitory effects on inflammasome activation triggered by various antidepressants.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely preclinical model based on abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism by which licorice extract (LE) affects nasal polyps (NPs), focusing on fibroblast differentiation, extracellular matrix production, and cell migration.
results_summary: Licorice extract significantly reduced eosinophil count, α-SMA expression, and interstitial collagen in NPs, attenuated fibroblast differentiation and ECM production, and suppressed cell migration, likely by inhibiting the MAPK/ERK-1/2 signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Patients with nasal polyps (NPs) undergoing nasal irrigation with licorice extract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anticancer properties of licorice (Glycyrrhiza glabra L.) and its bioactive constituents, focusing on molecular mechanisms and potential clinical applications.
results_summary: Licorice constituents demonstrated multiple anticancer effects (antiproliferative, antiangiogenic, antimetastatic, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory) by inhibiting various cellular targets, with no evident toxicity in in vitro and in vivo models. Emerging evidence supports licorice as a potential anticancer agent, though toxicity-related obstacles remain for clinical application.
population_specificity: In vitro and in vivo models (not human-specific).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active components of licorice flavonoids responsible for anti-atherosclerotic effects and their underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study identified isoliquiritigenin (ISL) as a key active component in licorice flavonoids that attenuates NLRP3-mediated vascular endothelial cell pyroptosis via SIRT6, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for atherosclerosis.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) treated with TNF-α.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether licorice ethanol extract (LEE) improves hepatic lipid accumulation in obese mice fed a high-fat diet (HFD) and whether gut microbiota plays a key role in LEE's efficacy.
results_summary: LEE improved obesity, lipid profiles, and liver fat accumulation in HFD mice and modulated gut microbiota, but had no effect in pseudo-sterile mice. Glycyrrhetic acid (GA) was more effective than glycyrrhizin (GL) in reducing fat accumulation in hepatocytes.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether licorice (Glycyrrhiza uralensis) strips at field edges enhance generalist predator abundance and improve aphid biological control in cotton crops.
results_summary: Licorice strips significantly increased predator abundance (2.2-4.3 fold) and reduced aphid density (17.5-61.2%) during peak infestation, while improving predator-to-aphid ratios (12.3-14.6 fold higher) and biocontrol services (2.8 times higher in 2020, 1.4 times in 2021).
population_specificity: Cotton cropping systems in Xinjiang, China.
study_duration: Field trials conducted over two years (2020 and 2021).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active ingredients in licorice and their mechanisms of action in treating COVID-19, focusing on inflammatory and oxidative stress pathways.
results_summary: The study found that licorice components Glycyrol, Phaseol, and Glyasperin F may treat COVID-19 by targeting STAT3, IL2RA, MMP1, and CXCL8, reducing inflammation and promoting tissue repair. Molecular dynamics confirmed stable binding of these compounds to their targets.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify potential modulators of the Pregnane X receptor (PXR) in Licorice extracts and assess their role in herb-drug interactions.
results_summary: The study identified glabridin as the most potent PXR activator among tested compounds, with computational and in vitro methods confirming its stable interaction with PXR, suggesting a potential mechanism for Licorice-induced drug interactions.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and computational study)
interactions: Potential herb-drug interactions via PXR activation were noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the anti-fibrotic effect of licorice compared to colchicine on areca nut-induced fibroblasts.
results_summary: Licorice extract reduced collagen accumulation in areca nut and CCl4-induced fibroblasts, with maximum reduction at 200 μg/ml. The results were statistically significant (P < 0.05) for both 24 and 48-hour periods.
population_specificity: Human fibroblast cell lines (PSC-201-018) induced with areca nut extract or CCl4.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of licorice hydroalcoholic extract as a natural remedy for improving biochemical and uterine tissue markers in ovariectomized rats, simulating postmenopausal conditions.
results_summary: The licorice extract improved calcium, estrogen, and progesterone levels, reduced alkaline phosphatase, and showed positive stereological and histopathological effects in uterine tissues, likely due to its phytoestrogen content and antioxidant activity.
population_specificity: Female Sprague-Dawley rats (ovariectomized to model postmenopausal conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the anticancer potential of isoliquiritigenin (ISL) from licorice, particularly its role in redox regulation, autophagy, and metabolic dysfunction in pancreatic cancer.
results_summary: The study found that ISL, a natural antioxidant from licorice, may help regulate redox homeostasis and autophagy, potentially inhibiting metabolic reprogramming and tumorigenesis in pancreatic cancer. It highlighted ISL's diversified functions, including antioxidation and metabolic regulation, as key mechanisms in its anticancer effects.
population_specificity: Pancreatic cancer (in vitro or preclinical context, not explicitly specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of licorice root supplementation on liver enzymes, hepatic steatosis, and metabolic/oxidative stress parameters in women with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Licorice root supplementation significantly improved liver enzymes (ALT), insulin levels, insulin resistance, oxidative stress (MDA), and liver steatosis compared to placebo, alongside lifestyle modifications.
population_specificity: 60 women with NAFLD.
effective_dosage: 1,000 mg/day powder of licorice root extract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanism of Licorice Green Tea Beverage (LGTB) in scavenging oxygen free radicals and its potential therapeutic effects on aging and oxidative stress-related diseases.
results_summary: The study found that LGTB effectively scavenged oxygen free radicals in vitro, protected HaCaT cells from oxidative stress, and improved antioxidant capacity in mice by increasing SOD and CAT activity and inhibiting the PI3K/AKT/HIF-1 signaling pathway.
population_specificity: HaCaT cells (human keratinocytes) and mice (D-galactose-induced aging model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between prolonged licorice use and preoperative hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and ECG abnormalities in an elderly patient.
results_summary: The study found that licorice induced pseudo-aldosteronism, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis in the patient, leading to hypoxemia and ECG abnormalities during surgery. Symptoms improved after discontinuing licorice and administering potassium chloride.
population_specificity: An 87-year-old woman with knee osteoarthritis scheduled for total knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of licorice-related medicines as an adjuvant regimen with chemotherapy to improve quality of life and reduce side effects.
results_summary: The study found that licorice-containing herbs and their active ingredients may reduce adverse reactions from chemotherapy and radiotherapy and improve patients' quality of life, though high-quality, large-scale RCTs are lacking.
population_specificity: Cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the multiple therapeutic effects of licorice on ulcerative colitis (UC) using meta-analysis and network pharmacology in preclinical studies.
results_summary: Licorice extract and its active compounds showed strong therapeutic effects in UC, including reduced histological scores, reversed colonic shortness, and significant reduction of TNF-α levels. Network pharmacology suggested anti-inflammatory, anti-oxidative, immunomodulatory, and microbiota-balancing mechanisms.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (animal models of ulcerative colitis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Glycyrrhiza glabra (licorice) on growth performance, blood parameters, antioxidant activity, and gene expression in broiler chickens.
results_summary: Licorice supplementation at 0.4 g/L improved body weight, feed intake, and intestinal morphology, enhanced antioxidant activity, and upregulated growth-related and lipid metabolism genes. It also increased CD3-positive cells in the intestine, indicating immunostimulant effects.
population_specificity: One-week-old Cobb500 broiler chickens (180 chicks).
effective_dosage: 0.4 g/L and 0.8 g/L in drinking water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate anti-pseudo-allergic compounds in licorice and evaluate their effects on MRGPRX2, a key target for pseudo-allergic reactions.
results_summary: Glycyrrhizic acid (GA) and licorice chalcone A (LA) from licorice inhibited degranulation and calcium influx in RBL-2H3 cells, MPMCs, and reduced histamine and TNF-α in mice. LA was identified as a potential ligand for MRGPRX2.
population_specificity: Rat basophilic leukemia cells (RBL-2H3), mouse peritoneal mast cells (MPMCs), and mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect and underlying mechanism of glabridin (a bioactive component of licorice) on diabetic nephropathy, focusing on ferroptosis and the VEGF/Akt/ERK pathway.
results_summary: Glabridin improved renal function and pathological changes in diabetic rats, reduced ferroptosis markers, and suppressed the VEGF/Akt/ERK pathway both in vivo and in vitro.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats and high glucose-induced NRK-52E cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the extraction, purification, structural characterization, pharmacological activities, and medicinal applications of licorice polysaccharides (LPs) to explore their potential as advanced biomaterials.
results_summary: The study found that licorice polysaccharides (LPs) have diverse pharmacological activities and can be modified for advanced applications such as drug delivery systems, biosensors, and vaccine synergism. The conformation and structural modifications of LPs play a crucial role in their functionality and interaction with other molecules.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacological potential of Licorice-derived bioactive compounds, focusing on their anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties for treating intestinal disorders.
results_summary: The study found that Licorice and its compounds exhibit anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antitumor effects, which may be beneficial for treating inflammatory bowel diseases and colorectal cancer. The mechanisms of action suggest therapeutic potential for intestinal disorders.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of pharmacological properties).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if licorice could detoxify cadmium (Cd) in mice and improve liver and gut health.
results_summary: Licorice reduced blood Cd by >50% in one month, decreased Cd in heart and lung tissues, but increased Cd in the liver. It improved liver health, induced Cd accumulation in hepatic cells, and altered gut microbiota, enriching Parabacteroides distasonis.
population_specificity: Mice with cadmium poisoning

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether licorice extract could enhance the efficacy of aminoglycoside antibiotics, particularly gentamicin, against *Listeria monocytogenes*.
results_summary: The study found that licorice extract significantly enhanced the antimicrobial effect of gentamicin, reducing its MIC by 32-fold and restoring susceptibility in resistant *L. monocytogenes* isolates. The results suggest licorice extract could serve as an antibiotic adjuvant for listeriosis treatment.
population_specificity: *Listeria monocytogenes* bacterial strains, including clinical isolates.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dietary licorice extract on the immune status of rainbow trout fingerlings.
results_summary: Licorice extract at 2 g kg-1 (LE2) significantly enhanced immune parameters, including white blood cell counts, serum immunoglobulin levels, lysozyme activity, and gene expression of immune-associated markers, while reducing mortality from Yersinia ruckeri infection. LE2 and LE3 treatments showed the most pronounced improvements in skin mucosal immunity and bactericidal activity.
population_specificity: Rainbow trout fingerlings (initial mean weight: 10.0 ± 0.1 g)
effective_dosage: 0.5, 1, 2, and 3 g kg-1 of licorice extract in diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different mulching methods on licorice root yield, soil organic carbon (SOC) changes, and the accumulation of active compounds (liquiritin and glycyrrhizin).
results_summary: Licorice root yield and active compound accumulation were significantly higher with mulching treatments (SM, RP, FP) compared to no mulching (CK). SM increased SOC content and related metrics, while RP and FP showed greater production stability but decreased SOC over time. The simulated RS treatment (straw incorporation plus plastic film mulch) balanced high yield with sustained SOC levels.
population_specificity: Licorice (Glycyrrhiza uralensis Fisch.) cultivated under field conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify natural SARS-CoV-2 inhibitors from licorice and evaluate their antiviral potential against COVID-19.
results_summary: The study found that licorice-derived compounds (licorice-saponin A3 and glycyrrhetinic acid) effectively inhibited SARS-CoV-2 infection by targeting viral entry and replication, with EC50 values of 75 nM and 3.17 µM, respectively.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (concentrations used: 75 nM for A3, 3.17 µM for GA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a mixture of Jinan Red Ginseng and licorice extract could reduce NASH progression by modulating inflammation, fibrosis, and lipid metabolism.
results_summary: The JRG-licorice mixture (JRG-M) effectively reduced NASH-related pathologies, decreased inflammatory and fibrotic gene expression, and lowered lipogenesis markers like SREBP-1c and FAS, outperforming JRG alone in some aspects.
population_specificity: WD-fed mice with induced NASH.
study_duration: Last half-period of diet feeding (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether licorice extract could inhibit the germination and outgrowth of *Paraclostridium bifermentans* spores in vacuum-packaged meat.
results_summary: Licorice extract effectively prevented spore germination at concentrations ≥ 1.56 mg/ml and inhibited outgrowth at 0.39 mg/ml. Key bioactive compounds like glycyrrhizic acid and liquiritin apioside were identified as responsible for the inhibitory effects.
population_specificity: *Paraclostridium bifermentans* spores isolated from vacuum-packaged chicken.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-ulcerative colitis (UC) activity of licoflavone B (LB) derived from licorice residue flavones and explore its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: High-dose LB (120 mg/kg) significantly prevented UC symptoms in mice, including weight loss, disease activity index increase, and colonic inflammation. LB also preserved intestinal barrier integrity and reshaped gut microflora by suppressing harmful bacteria and promoting beneficial microorganisms, likely through blocking the MAPK pathway.
population_specificity: DSS-exposed C57BL/6 mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the use of licorice as a herbal-based coloring agent for cotton dyeing under ultrasonic treatment and assess the impact of bio-mordants on color strength.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasonic treatment enhanced the color depth of licorice extract on cotton fabric, with specific bio-mordants (acacia, henna, pomegranate, turmeric) and chemical mordants (salts of Al and Fe) improving color strength. The best results were achieved with Fe salts (3%) as pre-mordant and turmeric extract (7%) as post-mordant.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on cotton fabric)
effective_dosage: Methanolic extract of licorice bark, ultrasonic treatment for 20 min, bio-mordants at 1-7%, chemical mordants at 3-7%
study_duration: Ultrasonic treatment for 20 min, dyeing at 65°C for 45 min

study_goal: The researchers aimed to comprehensively review the ethnopharmacological uses, phytochemistry, biological activities, clinical evidence, and toxicology of licorice to establish its pharmacological effects and molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that licorice root extracts have various beneficial effects, including treating infections, respiratory and liver diseases, and exhibiting antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, and immunomodulatory properties. It also highlighted the potential of licorice as a natural alternative for treating chronic diseases with mild side effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad review of historical and potential applications)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of licorice (Glycyrrhiza glabra) as a natural intervention for COVID-19 symptoms, focusing on its antiviral, anti-inflammatory, and autophagy-enhancing properties.
results_summary: The study suggests licorice's phytochemicals exhibit antiviral and anti-inflammatory properties, with one component potentially enhancing autophagy, which may be beneficial for COVID-19 treatment. The authors recommend further in vitro, in vivo, and clinical trials to explore these effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of licorice phytochemicals as antiviral agents against SARS-CoV-2, focusing on their binding affinity to the virus's main protease and their in vitro anti-SARS-CoV-2 activity.
results_summary: The study identified several licorice compounds with strong binding affinities to SARS-CoV-2 Mpro, demonstrated robust in vitro anti-SARS-CoV-2 activity, and suggested glycyrrhizin as particularly effective with a lower IC50 than licorice extract.
population_specificity: In vitro (cell-based) study, not human subjects.
study_duration: Not specified for in vitro experiments; 100 ns molecular dynamics simulation for selected compounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether licorice flavonoid oil (LFO) could increase muscle mass and suppress body fat percentage in elderly populations undergoing rehabilitation for knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that LFO significantly increased trunk muscle mass and suppressed body fat percentage in elderly participants after 16 weeks of supplementation compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (54-90 years, 7 men, 43 women) undergoing rehabilitation for knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether licorice supplementation improves obesity indices, glycemic control, and lipid profiles in overweight/obese women with PCOS when combined with a low-calorie diet.
results_summary: Licorice supplementation significantly improved obesity indices (body weight, BMI, body fat), lipid profiles (TG, TC, LDL-C, HDL-C), glycemic control (FBS, insulin levels, HOMA-IR, HOMA-B) compared to placebo, even after adjusting for confounders.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) (n=66).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of a liquid placebo for STW5, an herbal medicinal product containing licorice, by comparing its sensory attributes with potential placebo candidates.
results_summary: The study found that an aged Maggi™ placebo was more viable for clinical trials with STW5 compared to other placebo options, though participants noted distinct differences in the mint flavor and smell of STW5. The placebos were similar in appearance, smell, and taste but required further adjustments to better mimic STW5's aromatic profile.
population_specificity: 60 healthy volunteers (30 in each of two trials)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Licorice flavonoid oil (LFO) reduces body weight, body fat, and improves metabolic markers in overweight/obese individuals and athletic men under overfeeding conditions.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant effects of LFO on any measured variables in either study. However, in the overfeeding condition, LFO showed a non-significant trend toward attenuating fat gain and blood lipid elevation.
population_specificity: Overweight or grade I-II obese men and women (Study 1); athletic men under overfeeding conditions (Study 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of repeated low-level red-light (RLRL) therapy in stabilizing axial elongation and refractive changes in adolescents with mild to moderate myopia, while also examining its impact on retinal blood flow density.
results_summary: RLRL therapy showed stable axial length and improved spherical equivalent refraction (SER) at six months, with no significant changes in secondary outcomes or observed side effects. The therapy maintained retinal blood flow density without adverse effects.
population_specificity: Adolescents (mean age 11.5 ± 1.72) with mild to moderate myopia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the knowledge, attitude, and practice (KAP) of aesthetic medicine practitioners regarding laser and/or light therapy for hypertrophic scars.
results_summary: The study found significant positive correlations between knowledge, attitude, and practice scores among practitioners, with knowledge and attitude scores significantly associated with proactive practice. The findings suggest a need for targeted education to improve practitioners' knowledge in this area.
population_specificity: Aesthetic medicine practitioners at Hebei Medical University Third Hospital (424 participants, 52.26% female).
study_duration: Data collected from December 25, 2023, to January 7, 2024 (cross-sectional study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the neurobiological mechanisms of bright light therapy (BLT) in subthreshold depression (StD) by examining dynamic functional connectivity (dFC) changes in the cingulate cortex (CC) and their correlation with neurotransmitter activity.
results_summary: BLT reduced depressive symptoms (CESD and HDRS scores) and altered dFC in the CC, with specific connectivity changes correlating with symptom improvement. Baseline dFC variability in the CC predicted treatment response, and dFC changes were linked to neurotransmitter activity, suggesting potential antidepressant mechanisms.
population_specificity: Adults with subthreshold depression (StD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of low-energy delicate pulsed light (DPL) therapy for treating sensitive skin.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in sensitivity scores, facial erythema, and skin redness, with no observed adverse effects. Statistical analyses confirmed the effectiveness of DPL therapy across different patient subgroups.
population_specificity: 181 patients with sensitive skin, including subgroups with rosacea, acne, or dermatitis.
effective_dosage: 5.0-6.8 J/cm², administered at 4-week intervals based on condition severity.
study_duration: Varying durations based on individual treatment plans (from January 2019 to January 2022).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of light therapy (LT) for improving sleep quality in individuals with insomnia.
results_summary: The study found that LT significantly improved subjective sleep quality (reduced PSQI and ISI scores) and objective sleep measures (increased total sleep time and decreased wake after sleep onset). The results suggest LT has some efficacy for insomnia, though further validation is needed.
population_specificity: Individuals with insomnia complaints

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of morning bright light therapy (MBLT) as a behavioral sleep intervention in Veterans with mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) through a randomized controlled trial.
results_summary: The study found MBLT to be feasible and acceptable, with high adherence (>85%) and low dropout rates (<10%). Primary outcomes focused on sleep measures, though efficacy results were not explicitly detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Veterans with a history of mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI).
effective_dosage: 60-minute duration within 2 hours of waking, daily over 28 days.
study_duration: 28 days of intervention, with follow-up assessments 28 days post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effective dose and efficacy of phototherapy in alleviating sleep disorders among shift workers.
results_summary: Light therapy significantly improved total sleep time (TST) and sleep efficiency (SE) in shift workers, with medium illuminance (900-6000 lx) for long durations (≥1 h) being more effective for TST, while higher illuminance and increasing dose (lx*h) benefited SE more.
population_specificity: Shift workers with sleep disorders.
effective_dosage: Medium illuminance (900-6000 lx) for long durations (≥1 h) during night; higher illuminance and increasing dose (lx*h) for SE.
